Welcome to PythonA Level-1 Heading

  • âPython scripts are plain text files.â
  • âUse the Jupyter Notebook for editing and running Python.â
  • âThe Notebook has Command and Edit modes.â
  • âUse the keyboard and mouse to select and edit cells.â
  • âThe Notebook will turn Markdown into pretty-printed documentation.â
  • âMarkdown does most of what HTML does.â

Variables in Python

  • Python is an interpreted programming language, and can be used interactively.
  • Values are assigned to variables in Python using =.
  • You can use print to output variable values.
  • Use meaningful variable names.

Basic Types

  • Every value has a type.
  • Use the built-in function type to find the type of a value.
  • Types control what operations can be done on values.
  • Strings can be added and multiplied.
  • Strings have a length (but numbers donât).

Built-in Functions and Help

  • âUse comments to add documentation to programs.â
  • âA function may take zero or more arguments.â
  • âCommonly-used built-in functions include max, min, and round.â
  • âFunctions may only work for certain (combinations of) arguments.â
  • âFunctions may have default values for some arguments.â
  • âUse the built-in function help to get help for a function.â
  • âPython reports a syntax error when it canât understand the source of a program.â
  • âPython reports a runtime error when something goes wrong while a program is executing.â

Libraries

  • âMost of the power of a programming language is in its libraries.â
  • âA program must import a library module in order to use it.â
  • âUse help to learn about the contents of a library module.â
  • âImport specific items from a library to shorten programs.â
  • âCreate an alias for a library when importing it to shorten programs.â

Lists

  • â[value1, value2, value3, ...] creates a list.â
  • âLists can contain any Python object, including lists (i.e., list of lists).â
  • âLists are indexed and sliced with square brackets (e.g., list[0] and list[2:9]), in the same way as strings and arrays.â
  • âLists are mutable (i.e., their values can be changed in place).â
  • âStrings are immutable (i.e., the characters in them cannot be changed).â

For Loops

  • âA for loop executes commands once for each value in a collection.â
  • âA for loop is made up of a collection, a loop variable, and a body.â
  • âThe first line of the for loop must end with a colon, and the body must be indented.â
  • âIndentation is always meaningful in Python.â
  • âLoop variables can be called anything (but it is strongly advised to have a meaningful name to the looping variable).â
  • âThe body of a loop can contain many statements.â
  • âUse range to iterate over a sequence of numbers.â

Pandas DataFrames

  • âUse DataFrame.iloc[..., ...] to select values by integer location.â
  • âUse : on its own to mean all columns or all rows.â
  • âSelect multiple columns or rows using DataFrame.loc and a named slice.â
  • âResult of slicing can be used in further operations.â
  • âUse comparisons to select data based on value.â
  • âSelect values or NaN using a Boolean mask.â

Conditionals

  • âUse if statements to control whether or not a block of code is executed.â
  • âConditionals are often used inside loops.â
  • âUse else to execute a block of code when an if condition is not true.â
  • âUse elif to specify additional tests.â
  • âConditions are tested once, in order.â

Writing Functions

  • âBreak programs down into functions to make them easier to understand.â
  • âDefine a function using def with a name, parameters, and a block of code.â
  • âDefining a function does not run it.â
  • âArguments in a function call are matched to its defined parameters.â
  • âFunctions may return a result to their caller using return.â
